name: Ananda-Rajah, Michelle MP
content: I was interrupted earlier, and I will continue to discuss this very important bill that is being presented by an Albanese government, the Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (Cheaper Child Care) Bill 2022. In my electorate of Higgins, there are 4,400 families who are eligible for child care. In 2020, 1,365 babies were born. Those babies are now toddlers, and their mothers and their families are struggling. I heard this during the campaign, and I hear this as I walk through the electorate. In Malvern, a young mother clutching her child is paying $165 a day. In Armadale its even higher, at $200 a day. What really shocked me was when I was in Carnegie and I met a working mum who came out from her Zoom call and said: Michelle, I am paying $2,000 a month on child care, but Im still doing it. Why? Because my career is important to me.So I saw firsthand the effects of what neglect around this policy is doing to my constituents, and it is a terrible drag on our economic prosperity. Those opposite had messed-up, warped priorities. We in the Albanese government have got our priorities right. We do not regard cheaper child care as middle-class welfare. We see it as a nation-building economic reform. In fact, our Minister Rishworth has previously called it nation-building infrastructure, which I thought was interesting because we dont conventionally regard infrastructure as being service delivery. But this is, in fact, infrastructure. It is the scaffolding that is going to build a better future for families, for children and for our economy.So we are now going to pull the biggest lever that we can to boost female workforce participation, and it cant come soon enough. Our country is currently in the grip of a labour and skills crisis. Our businesses are desperate for workers, and it is a constraint on our growth. So we desperately need more women in the economy as a matter of urgency, and this bill will do that. In fact, it will unlock the equivalent of 37,000 full-time workers into the economy. Just imagine—just like that. When it passes, thats what it could do.We do not regard it as welfare. We regard this as a generational economic reform with an economic dividend. Ive said previously that the worst kind of spending results in a liability. The best kind of spending is an investment, and this is an investment—close to $5 billion in investment for our children, for our women, for mothers, for families and for our economy. Under the bill, from July 2023, the childcare subsidy will increase to a maximum of 90 per cent for families with a combined taxable income of up to $80,000. With increasing family income, the childcare subsidy will then taper down until it cuts out at a combined income of $530,000. Now, that is very generous. We will retain the higher childcare subsidy for families with more than one child under the age of five, because we recognise the financial burden imposed on families with multiple children. This bill will leave 96 per cent of families better off. Basically, most families are going to benefit from this. No-one will be worse off.With this bill, we have reshaped early childhood education and care as an economic reform. It is an investment in our children that improves their school readiness and long-term outcomes. It is an investment in women, with our nation the recipient of a pool of talent no longer sitting on a shelf, latent, but firing up our productivity.
subdebateinfo: Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (Cheaper Child Care) Bill 2022
Speaker: Dr ANANDA-RAJAH (Higgins)

name: McIntosh, Melissa MP
content: I am not new to talking about the need for childcare reform. In fact, seven years ago I was heavily involved in this discussion. I was talking about the need for reform and it not just being about putting money into the pockets of parents. In fact, we needed a change to the childcare structure and the creation of support systems for working parents. Financial support is not the be-all and end-all that we require. I still believe in structural changes and better ways of doing things, in looking for solutions that support women who want to stay in their careers and solutions for families, who are the backbone of our countrys prosperity.But here we are again, seven years on, and we are only talking about the financial support for parents, not the other significant issues that we are faced with when it comes to skills shortages in child care, when it comes to the standards of childcare centres and, of course, when it comes to the accessibility of child care, which I feel in my metropolitan Western Sydney seat of Lindsay. But I do support measures—of course I do—that provide cheaper child care for families in my electorate, particularly for families who are doing it tough. I just dont think that this is the measure that we should be looking at in an economic environment of sky-high inflation. As I said, I dont think this bill looks at or addresses workforce shortages, it doesnt address the lack of access to child care, and it doesnt address the standard of care or the quality of that care. These continue to be some of the biggest issues facing the childcare sector.As I highlighted, one of the key areas I am addressing is that this bill fails to address skills shortages in child care. And it doesnt matter what business I go to in my electorate of Lindsay, businesses are crying out for more workers, and they are certainly doing that in the childcare sector. Even when I was attempting to speak with them about this bill, they were just too busy—theyre so busy—because they cant get enough workers and they just dont have time to stop and think or to really contribute in the way that they want to, and they express this. Theyre so busy looking after kids, and they cant get enough workers help them. Its something that needs to be addressed, foremost, before we even look at financial support. If you dont have enough workers, that means you dont have enough childcare places. Therefore, parents who might have financial support behind them certainly cant their get their kids into the childcare centres. This needs to change, and I think the government has failed to identify these existing shortages and to forecast areas of demand in the labour market. I think the government needs to invest more in our own workforce, in our future workforce. Investment in training is something that childcare centres and the childcare sector have said to me is really important—training our future childcare educators in the best way possible so theyre giving our kids the best start in their lives and before they start school. So the government must do more to secure the supply of skills we need right here in Australia.As I highlighted, the bill fails to address those extremely long waitlists that see families leaving their local area in the search, in the hunt, for a childcare centre, which sort of defeats the purpose of putting your child in care and trying to get off to work. As a parent who travelled over an hour each way to work for many years—for over 10 years—I understand that sometimes its about getting your kids into care as quickly as possible, getting on the train and doing the commute so you can get home as quickly as possible and not have to do a long drive out of the area to find a childcare centre that will take your child. Of course, this touches on the accessibility of opening hours for childcare centres too. If you cant get a centre thats close to you, you have to pick your child up later, and a lot of centres do not cater for that. So there are multiple issues, which I addressed at the start of the speech, which need to be looked at seriously. Its not just about money, as important as it is, in the pockets of families. We have centres that are now capping because they dont have the workforce, and childcare centre operators that are worried that without some sort of fix from government these long waitlists will continue and will get worse as time goes on.This bill also fails to address the lack of childcare services, which I just discussed. Its a familiar tale: due to the lack of access to childcare places, a partner must make the difficult decision either to give up work or not return to work in order to provide care. In most instances its the female partner who must make this sacrifice. I understand that very well, as a working mum who has worked since all my children were very small. Its a tough decision and quite often very much a financial decision. This is hurting productivity in Australia and adversely impacting women who would otherwise choose to return to work. Having lower out-of-pocket costs when you cant even get your children into care really doesnt make any sense at all.A report earlier this year from the Mitchell Institute showed that around one-third of Australian families, nine million Australians, live in an area where there is only one place for every three children. Its not just regional areas that have a lack of childcare services. Fifty per cent of childcare deserts are located, as we in Western Sydney know very well, in metro locations. We should be asking: what is the government doing to secure those extra places and ensure theyre created for these families who need spaces the most? Where are the additional places going to open for all these children that will be coming into the system? The government must improve access to care, and address these gaps.The Albanese government is certainly delivering its first budget against a backdrop of soaring inflation. Despite this putting households under pressure, the government is not being careful enough and is instead fuelling inflation with excessive expenditure in this budget. As I said, the budget does not even come close to addressing the structural changes and reform that need to happen to get more women into the workforce, to support working families—who are the backbone of our country—and to provide more childcare places and more accessible childcare places, particularly in areas like mine in Western Sydney. Supporting the bill is important from this perspective, because we do want to ensure that families are able to make the choice to return to work if they wish to do so. But you cant make that choice if you dont have the access or local places.In conclusion, I think theres a lot more work that needs to be done, and a lot more consideration needs to be given to families who are having that discussion and making that choice about whether they do go to work and contribute financially to our economy—as we know, we have those extreme workforce shortages—or they stay at home with their children purely because they cannot get those childcare places.
subdebateinfo: Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (Cheaper Child Care) Bill 2022
Speaker: Mrs McINTOSH (Lindsay)

name: Byrnes, Alison MP
content: I stand today to speak in favour of the Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (Cheaper Child Care) Bill 2022. This bill will make child care more affordable for around 1.26 million Australian families. Around 5,700 families in Cunningham will be better off because of this bill. Thats 5,700 local families who will have more money to spend on food, clothing, and fuel—the necessities that are increasingly more expensive. This bill is also important for gender equality. Women still face a gender pay gap of around 14 per cent, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, and Australian tax office data has shown that womens superannuation balances are still falling behind mens. With this bill, the women of Cunningham and Australia will be better placed to pursue their careers and build their superannuation balances for retirement.By making child care more affordable for many Australians, more children will be able to receive an early education. It is this early education that is so important to the development of children. It provides opportunities to learn and socialise, to develop independence and to get a good start in life.In the recent school holidays, I caught up with a part-time working mum, who shared her story with me. Like so many mums, she is trying to raise her family and build her career at the same time. Her two children are aged two and six and attend child care and public school three to four days a week. Of course, there are bills to pay and theres food to buy, but her daily expenses just to turn up to work are something we all need to pay attention to. There is $74 for child care, after the childcare subsidy; $19 for parking; $34 for a holiday program, after the childcare subsidy; and $10 for petrol to and from work, school, and child care. Thats nearly $140 gone, and this hardworking mum has not even started her day at work. If she buys lunch, she will probably break even for the day.Over the past eight years, childcare costs have increased by 41 per cent. ABS figures show that, in 2021, 73,000 people who wanted to work did not look for work, because of childcare costs. Thats 73,000 people who could have been contributing to our economy and helping to address the workforce crisis. Australians deserve better, and they have elected Labor to do just that. The cheaper childcare bill will lift the maximum childcare subsidy rate from 85 to 90 per cent for families with a combined income of under $80,000. It will also increase childcare subsidy rates for families earning less than $530,000. For the second child and any subsequent children aged five or younger, the higher childcare subsidy will also still apply. A family on a combined income of $120,000 with one child in care will save $1,780 in the first year. With these changes, around 96 per cent of families using early childhood education and care will be better off.This bill also increases transparency and helps strengthen integrity in the sector. It will require large childcare providers to report on revenue and profits to the Department of Education. This information can then be made available online to families, enabling more informed choices for consumers, which is a good change for transparency and greater integrity.We are all aware that the care sector in this country has a workforce crisis. So many industries are crying out for skilled workers, workers that keep our country running and care for our loved ones. The early childhood education and care sector is no different. Last week, as part of Early Learning Matters Week, I visited with Kelly and the team at Kids Uni at Wollongong University. As I spoke with the workers, it was clear that they are passionate about education and helping kids to get the best start in life. They love the industry, they love the kids, and their knowledge and professionalism is incredible. We need more childhood educators like the wonderful team at Kids Uni.This bill will help encourage and retain early childhood educators by enabling childcare providers to offer a discount to their staff. It is a good change for the workers. The Albanese Labor government is helping Australian families give their young children the best start in life. We are making early childhood education more affordable and transparent, giving families the support they need in these difficult times. We are supporting modern families to balance their career and caring responsibilities in a way that works for them. I commend the bill to the House.
subdebateinfo: Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (Cheaper Child Care) Bill 2022
Speaker: Ms BYRNES (Cunningham)

name: Ware, Jenny MP
content: I rise to support this amendment to the Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (Cheaper Child Care) Bill 2022. This side of the House supports the bill in principle. I speak on the sensible amendments put forward by the member for Moncrieff. I have risen a number of times in this place to talk about the impacts of the increasing cost of living and the struggles Australian families are facing. Child care is a major cost outlay for families, including those in my electorate of Hughes.It is not just the cost of child care that I wish to speak about tonight. It is also about the childhood educators and the quality of care that is being provided. I have a personal interest in this. When my boys, James and Nicholas, were toddlers, I was on the parent board of their local preschool. I have a great commitment to and a personal interest in both the quality and quantity of early childhood places. If I had not been able to put my children into care at that stage, I would not have been able to continue my career when my children were very small.I support incentives, including those proposed in this bill, that assist parents paying for high-quality childcare places. It is well known that access to childcare places significantly raises the participation rate of women in the workforce. I also acknowledge the work of early childhood educators, who are providing an essential service benefiting our youngest Australians and preparing them for a lifetime of education. These educators have been under pressure due to the pandemic over the last couple of years. This bill seeks to extend measures introduced under the former coalition government to assist families during the COVID-19 pandemic with fee relief. The bill does increase the childcare subsidy for parents. That is to be applauded. However, an increase in subsidies does not actually mean that there is any increase in childcare places. The bill provides a monetary figure of $4.5 billion, but not one single cent of that $4.5 billion will be spent to create additional places or improve the quality of services being provided. The bill remains silent on details, including having no plan to address the current workforce shortages, no plan to address access to care and no plan to address the thin markets and childcare deserts, many of which are in regional areas. I note that many on my side of the House have spoken about this and about the horrifying shortages in their regional electorates. This means that the government is proposing a very expensive measure, $4.5 billion, but with no clear plan of how additional places for children will be provided.The coalition believes in choice. We believe that parents who work or study should be able to access child care, whether through formal or informal arrangements. The coalition also believes in addressing concerns raised by childcare workers. These educators are at the coalface of delivering services to the most vulnerable, our children. We need to listen to them when they tell us that there are significant shortages of places. This bill does not address supply. Demand for childcare places around Australia is well outstripping supply and has been for some time. I know that many members on my side have already spoken about the shortages, particularly in the regional areas. But we need to listen better. We need to listen to childcare educators who tell us all the reasons that many of them are deserting the sector and going into other employment. This bill purports to increase the childcare subsidy for carers. However, with no increase in places, child care will simply cost more. Thats basic demand and supply. Its basic economics.The last time Labor was in government, childcare fees skyrocketed by 53 per cent in just six years. Out-of-pocket costs are already rising, and fees at childcare centres will most likely rise before 1 July 2023, when these measures are intended to come into place. This will presumably erode a significant amount of the increased subsidies before theyre even in place. If we contrast that with the coalitions record, over 280,000 more children are now in early childhood education, based on measures brought in under the former coalition government. This was achieved by abolishing the annual cap on the childcare subsidy. Around 90 per cent of families currently using the childcare subsidy are eligible for a subsidy of between 50 and 85 per cent.The previous coalition government targeted extra support that was introduced in March of this year made a real difference. We saw childcare costs come down immediately following March and through to June by 4.6 per cent in that quarter. We saw womens workforce participation reach record highs of 62.3 per cent in May of this year. Thats compared to 58.7 per cent when Labor last left office, in 2013.Through this bill, there is a stark lack of detail from the Albanese government. There is no plan to address the current workforce shortages, there is no plan to address access to care and there is no plan to address the already thin markets, particularly in our regional areas.Parents that I speak to in my electorate tell me that they need more places—that they could work additional days if there were additional places for their children. Childcare educators tell of the reasons they are leaving the sector. Labor pretends to be the friend of childcare workers. This bill does not reflect that. Of the $4.5 billion costed in this bill, not a single cent will be spent to create additional places or services. This is simply not good enough. What answer can the government provide to frustrated parents in the Hughes electorate and throughout Australia who cannot access sufficient childcare services?This bill also does nothing to address the struggles faced by our early childhood educators and does not look at the reasons why they are leaving the sector. These workers worked tirelessly through the pandemic, and now, on the other side, workers are leaving the sector in droves for other careers. Many educators have raised low wages, mental health issues, a lack of appreciation, increases in red tape and burnout as their top concerns, and there are currently more than 7,000 vacancies in the sector. What answer can the government provide to the early childhood educators leaving centres about how it will address their struggles? What answer can the government provide to the parents who may be receiving a higher subsidy but will be faced with higher costs and no increase in the number of places available to them?In 2019 the Labor Party campaigned on a platform of higher wages for early childhood educators. Now they are in government, they seem to have dropped parts of that platform, and this bill does nothing to address that. With more children set to enter child care from July 2023, how will the government ensure there is a workforce to meet the extra need? This is the real issue in the childcare sector. The governments proposed bill, with $4.5 billion of expenditure, does nothing to address fundamental issues about the quality of child care. The amendment proposed, however, goes to the heart of the real issues facing the childcare sector.Basic principles of liberalism promote the ideal that governments should facilitate an environment that empowers individuals to make their own choices for their lives, their families and their businesses. Without adequate childcare places, parents cannot make those decisions in relation to their own careers and in relation to the best needs of their family.To conclude, affordable and quality child care is of paramount importance to parents in my electorate and to Australian families throughout the country. It is a shame that the Labor government has squandered an opportunity to address the real issues in the childcare sector by not providing for additional spaces. For all of the reasons outlined, I commend the proposed amendment to the House.
subdebateinfo: Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (Cheaper Child Care) Bill 2022
Speaker: Ms WARE (Hughes)

name: Gorman, Patrick MP
content: I rise to speak on the Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (Cheaper Child Care) Bill 2022. My children are in child care this week. Its what enables me to be here to do my job and to lower the cost of child care for 6,800 families in my electorate. I want to start by saying, Thank you, to our early childhood educators: thank you for educating the next generation; thank you for making both our economy and our society work; thanks for all the work you do before you even step into an early education centre, in studying and learning about early childhood development. I know how important your work is, not just because of what Ive seen in my own children, which I will talk about more in a moment, but also because I have seen my mother do that work. My mum was an early childhood teacher for a number of decades. Im so proud of the work that Wendy has done in building up the next generation, and its always a delight whenever Im with her in Fremantle and one of her former students comes up to her and says, Thank you. To see the joy on both their faces is something incredibly special.We know our early educators and early childhood education give children the best start in life. Thats why I also say thank you to those who campaigned for this change—organisations like The Parenthood, Thrive by Five, the United Workers Union, the Chamber of Commerce and Industry in Western Australia, and centre directors and staff from across Australia, to name just a few. Ive seen the benefits of a quality early childhood education on my own household. Last week my son, Leo, turned five—happy birthday again, Leo! He never gets sick of hearing that. I give special congratulations to Jess, who met the objectives that he set out in a dinosaur-Lego-rocket-themed birthday cake. She met that brief well. Weve all heard the evidence that 90 per cent of brain development happens in the first five years. My son turned five—hes done! Hes 90 per cent done, 10 per cent to go. But Ive seen the benefits of that early learning. He writes stories, he writes songs, he can add and subtract, and he can count to 100. He can ask questions about anything, and his emotional intelligence has turned him into an incredibly kind and compassionate young person. I know that early-years education made that difference.One of the things I want to articulate in this debate is on how many different fronts this investment that we as a parliament are making delivers. Childcare investment delivers education for more Australians. This childcare investment will deliver support for vulnerable and disadvantaged children. It will deliver more emotional support for more Australian children. It will deliver on cost-of-living pressures, making sure that more people can afford to get their children into early education for more days. It will deliver on gender equality. It will deliver on higher superannuation balances for women. It will deliver more skills into our economy. It will deliver more prepared students into primary school and beyond. It will deliver improved literacy. It will deliver improved numeracy. It will deliver a growing Australian economy, and it is an investment in our nations future.Both sides of this House agree that Australia still has a way to go when it comes to achieving true gender equality. We know that we need to make those steps in that direction because it is not only the right thing to do and the overdue thing to do but also the smart thing to do. We know that so much more economic growth is available to this nation when we harness the full potential of all of us. We can also ensure that we provide increased financial security and more leadership opportunities and break what has been an accepted policy design in this place for too long, where the cost of child care presents itself as a barrier to women entering further into the workforce, forcing them to reduce their hours and to turn down opportunities. For many families, it often makes financial sense for a parent—often the mother—to stay at home and work fewer hours. In 2021 there were 73,000 people across this country who wanted to work but were not looking for work purely because of the cost of child care. Surely we can do something and surely we cannot go another year with that being the case. Thats why this legislation is so important.Its important that we recognise that we will be doing this within the first 12 months of the Albanese government. I dont know who else in this place had an opportunity to do something about this earlier. Ive even advocated in the past. I wrote in 2020 that I believed that the former Morrison government should have stolen the policy that we put out, which now-Prime Minister Albanese introduced in his budget reply.

name: MemberContinuation
content: Mr GORMAN: We owe it to those families who want more support to do something about it. Its as simple as that. The Treasury estimates about the impact of this bill are promising, suggesting it will increase the hours worked by women with young children by up to 1.4 million hours per week. Thats the equivalent of an extra 37,000 full-time workers. And its not just those workers who will benefit. We know that one-third of mothers work in industries facing severe shortages. They work in our hospitals, our aged-care homes, our schools and across our society, filling essential jobs in every facet of life. We want to help them get back into the workforce and fill those skills gaps.This will come into effect next year, some 80 years after the Commonwealth first engaged in the business of financially supporting what were then called—to quote John Curtin—women war workers, providing money for creches for their children. I think its amazing that, in the depths of World War II, that was the first time the Commonwealth engaged in the direct funding of early childhood education and care so that we could fill—again—skills gaps in our economy. I think its worth noting that, both times, it has been Labor that has made these big steps in the right direction to support families who want to work—who we as a society need to work—by supporting properly funded early childhood education and care.This bill shows that we are determined to support families, particularly in the times we face. We know how many Australian families are already struggling to make ends meet. Childcare fees increased some 41 per cent under the coalition government, meaning that parents, year on year under the Liberals and the Nationals, had to sit down and consider really difficult questions: How much money is left after paying the childcare bills? How many days should they or their partner work? Is it worth working the fourth or the fifth day? Those questions denied our economy workers and skills but also denied children access to the value of a high-quality early childhood education and care environment.What we see is, finally, a government that is absolutely determined to make sure we act on child care, act on this big cost-of-living pressure, at one of the most expensive times for families, when they have a new young person in the family. They are very demanding. They need lots of care and attention. And the bills do start to add up. So I would just say to those who are not yet convinced or who are maybe considering amendments to this legislation: lets get it through. Lets get it done. Families have waited for nine long years. They finally have a government that wants to act and which values early childhood education and the educators who work in this sector.Ill finish my remarks where I started: thank you to the educators of Australia. Thank you for what you do day in, day out to invest in and educate the next generation of Australians.

name: Wolahan, Keith MP
content: Often, when I read the news or I pick up the newspaper, I turn my mind to the late Christopher Hitchens and think, Id love to know what hed think of this issue or this time. He was once on Q+A and was asked about poverty. I think he had said it before, but he repeated it there: The cure for poverty has a name; its called the empowerment of women. When we look at nations that are poverty stricken, theres a correlation with how women are treated and are not given opportunities to work, to go to a bank, to borrow or to start a business—to do all of the things that not only lift them and their families but lift a nation. Child care is a part of that. Its a key part of it, and the coalition certainly acknowledges that.Before I go to what this means for my electorate of Menzies, Ill talk about another part of child care that matters—and I know its not available to everyone, for various reasons—which is grandparents. Ive been very fortunate, particularly through COVID, to have grandparents, my parents, who contributed to helping us with our children. I want to give a shout-out to all of the grandparents in my electorate. You carried an enormous burden through the last few years, and indeed you do all the time. Its often noted in logistics—the school drop-off, the school pick-up, sport, parties, minding—but its more than that. Its also the wisdom and love that we know we got from our parents and thats getting passed on to our children: to hear a perspective on what life was like before devices existed, to be a good person, to control your emotions and to live a good life. I know, again using my parents as an example, that these are all lessons that they are passing on. Again, not everyone has that; people live in different states, or their parents are overseas or their parents have passed away, so that option isnt available to all. So child care in the form that this bill seeks to address is important.Theres no denying that this bill, the Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (Cheaper Child Care) Bill 2022, does favour higher-income earners over lower-income earners, and we should wrestle with that. This isnt how we normally spend funds from this place; its not skewed that way normally. But I think we can look at that differently because, when you look at how much it costs to buy a home, theres a disparity between income and assets in this country. We know that there are younger people starting out in life who have high incomes on paper but have enormous costs, and a lot of them have very few assets. In time, they hope and they dream that they will address that and build an asset base for their family. But thats very hard when youre just starting out. Child care is a way for families to leverage the work that they have put into their education and the work that they have put into their careers. That choice should be available to all families. It is right and proper that we acknowledge that the bill is skewed towards higher-income earners, but that doesnt necessarily mean those people are asset rich. Thats just a fact of life in Australia.My seat, in particular, is a little bit older. It has 48,700 families and about 1.7 children per family. The average age is 42—I think the national average age in Australia is 39—and within that there are 6,790 childcare places and 115 childcare facilities. So this bill is important to my electorate as, indeed, it is important to others.The coalition believes in choice. Its one of the main reasons I joined the Liberal Party. And we believe that parents who work or study should be able to access care, whether through formal or informal arrangements, as I have mentioned. This isnt a perfect bill—no bill is—and its important that we acknowledge that. We think the plan to address the current workforce shortage needs work. We think the plan to access and find a place in child care needs work. These are not easy decisions. I think there isnt a workforce or an agency or a part of this economy or the Public Service that isnt struggling to find workers. These arent unique challenges. But that doesnt mean we shouldnt look at them. For the $4.5 billion, not one single cent will be spent to create additional places or services.Id like to briefly address some of their workforce pressures that exist. The pressures have been there for a while and through the previous government as well. Its important to note that those who work in child care work tirelessly, and they worked tirelessly throughout the pandemic. My family used child care as well as grandparents, and I was always amazed at the work that they did. I remember one day, when there was a duty roster for parents to come and help out, I said Ill put up my hand and do that. They gave me the brush and broom and asked me to clean up and to wash the paintbrushes and to do all the other things. I thought Id just be reading to some kids. I was exhausted by the end of that day, absolutely exhausted. And I said, I dont think I can do that and do my normal job as well. But the people who work in child care do that and so much more, and then they have their own families, and so they are superstars in terms of the work effort they do, and we thank them. They leave an impression on children and an impression on families, and they make our country stronger. But there are 7,200 vacancies in the sector. Part of that is pay, part of that is other opportunities, and a part of it is also that its just bloody hard work. Im sorry if its unparliamentary to say bloody. So we have asked the government several times about how many additional educators will be needed under this policy, and that answer has yet to come, at least in a satisfactory way.

content: Mr WOLAHAN: Nine thousand. I need to update my notes!When asked about it, they point to their fee-free TAFE places, which wont deliver an immediate relief to the workforce. Educators arent happy and are leaving when theyre overworked, and thats understandable. If there are vacancies in an area and youre having to carry more of the load, youll resent what youre doing and youll walk as well.Ive spoken to some centres in my electorate. Theyre capping enrolments. Theyre full. They dont want any more, or theyre at least caring for a proportionate number of children to the number of staff they have. Some of my regional colleagues have spoken about childcare deserts. Im not going to pretend that applies in my seat. It doesnt. Were lucky. Were near the city, so we do have enough places. Its the workforce shortages that really matter.Lets turn to the $4.5 billion blowout. I could tell the cliches about how Labor cant manage money and we can, but thats not going to help anyone in this debate. Lets look at the detail. Labor have changed the price tag of the policy three times. It was initially $5.4 billion, then $5.1 billion and now $4.5 billion. Its possible—indeed, probable—that this policy is undercooked, that its not fit for purpose or ready to go. Its been costed for only three days a week, and many families need so much more than that and will access so much more than that. So we ask the question, again: why has it not been costed for five days a week?And then there are the other cost-of-living pressures that are on families. We heard a lot of truths in the budget and some distortion of truths. So lets look at what people do and not what they say. The last time Labor was in government, childcare fees rocketed by 53 per cent in six years. So we will look at what you do, not what you say. Out-of-pocket costs are already rising and fees will most likely rise before 1 July 2023, and this may erode a significant amount of the increased subsidies before they are even in place.I notice the clock is running down. I too have a son, called Leo; hes 10. He benefited from child care, as did my daughter, Eva.This bill has a noble intent. It needs work.But can I just thank the workers in child care throughout this country and throughout my electorate. I tip my hat to you and I thank you for your service.
subdebateinfo: Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (Cheaper Child Care) Bill 2022
Speaker: N/A

name: Burnell, Matt MP
content: I rise to speak in favour of the Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (Cheaper Child Care) Bill. This is yet more legislation that the Albanese Labor government has introduced to this place to follow through on an election commitment, which of itself is a worthy thing to be doing. This bill provides for lasting benefits across multiple generations which will endure for generations to come.Over the past eight years, childcare costs have risen by 41 per cent. This bill aims to ease cost-of-living pressures for many working families at a time where they, and, in fact, every Australian, need it the most. The cost of child care is a very expensive impost on many households and their family budgets. This is why I am pleased to support this bill at its most basic purpose.This is not a form of welfare; this is an economic reform—an economic reform with social dividends which will be felt in the years to come. It will increase the school-readiness of young Australians to give them the best possible chances of success in their schooling life leading into adulthood. Ninety-six per cent of families with children in early education will be better off under this bill—none will be worse off. Ninety-six per cent equates to 1.26 million families. This bill is an economic reform that increases our output and productivity and removes a common barrier to a childs ability to access an early learning environment that lays many foundations for a successful entry into primary school. This bill also helps to reduce many barriers to entry and re-entry to the workforce. Those barriers cost families immediately in their take-home pay but also in the long run when it comes to their super balances upon retirement.Another key aspect of this legislation is the positive impact on our First Nations children. This bill aims to help address objective 4 of our Closing the Gap targets: seeing our First Nations children thrive in their early years. Increasing their ability to access child care and early education will go a long way to achieving these outcomes, and so I am especially proud to be speaking in favour of this bill. It also allows for a base level of entitlement of the childcare subsidy of 36 hours per fortnight for First Nations children in child care, regardless of the activity levels of their family. This figure is slightly in excess of the recommended amount of child care, which is generally agreed upon to be 15 hours or two days per week. But, for others children, this bill will now open the door to many being able to attend child care—to receive access to that environment, where early educators develop social skills—alongside children in their age group. This is demonstrative of why this is a target of Closing the Gap: 95 per cent of all First Nations children enrolled in the early-learning system by the age of four by 2025. We need to ensure this target is met. Ensuring that a larger number of First Nations children are better prepared for school and have in their possession a core building block to a good start in life can go a long way to ensuring that we are moving in the right direction as a nation, not backwards, especially with respect to Closing the Gap targets like this one.I would also like to commend one of my South Australian colleagues, the member for Kingston, for her role as one of the main architects of this policy, back when she was the shadow minister for early childhood education, prior to this years election. I had the privilege of having the member for Kingston visit Spence in the lead-up to the federal election, along with Senator Farrell. Together, we visited the Hillbank community childcare centre, which is one of around 121 early learning centres within the Spence electorate. Rebecca from the Hillbank community childcare centre and her team of early childhood educators demonstrate a care and passion for their job that gives me a great deal of faith for the children in their care.My electorate of Spence in South Australia is home to well over 7,000 families—closer to around 7,500 families—that currently receive a childcare subsidy and will directly benefit as a result of this bill.With the mention of my home state, I would also like to mention the good work of the South Australian Malinauskas Labor government, particularly the Premiers recent announcement of a royal commission into early childhood education and care, which is being led by former Labor Prime Minister the Hon. Julia Gillard AC. The South Australian government, like the Albanese government, recognises the importance of early childhood education and care in the development of young minds—the future of our society. Governments of all levels working towards providing better access to child care for families and their children is positive indeed.Ultimately, this bill is fulfilling our commitment to working families to deliver cheaper child care for them. It is for these families and their children that I support this bill.
subdebateinfo: Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (Cheaper Child Care) Bill 2022
Speaker: Mr BURNELL (Spence)

name: Pasin, Tony MP
content: Im pleased that the member for Aston hasnt left the place, because he made a very valid point in his contribution and I want to reiterate it. He said that, when the Prime Minister addressed this bill yesterday, he suggested to the House that the member for Moncrieff and our government wasnt supportive of the bill. In so doing, he misled the House and he should, out of all decency, come back into the place and clarify his statement. The reality is that our party and the coalition support more affordable child care, but we also support more accessible child care.I will leave for others commentary about what this $4.5 billion will do in relation to the cost of child care, and I could wax lyrical about what happened last time when those opposite were in charge of the Treasury benches and the price of child care and how it billowed out of control. But, rather than do that, I want to address the challenges that people in my electorate are facing. A report earlier this year from the Mitchell institute showed that around one-third of Australian families—nine million Australians—live in a childcare desert. You might ask: A childcare desert? What could that be? Its been described as a place where theres one childcare place for every three children seeking a place.In my electorate, the Mitchell institute report indicated that the Limestone Coast had 4.93 children per place—a childcare desert. The Murray-Mallee region in South Australia had 4.7 children per place—a childcare desert. In Barossa, a place that people in this place could perhaps incorrectly assume is a necessarily affluent area, had 3.3 children per place—a childcare desert. This matters, because these are places in my electorate and all across the country where, whilst the affordability question is important, the issue for them is access. No amount of money allows a young mum or a young father to get back into the workforce, because child care is simply not available. I want to pause and tell the House that, in my electorate, there are some services in some of these deserts—mobile child care. It is child care out of the boot of a car.

name: MemberContinuation
content: Mr PASIN: I will take the interjection from the member for Spence. Its almost as if Id asked for it. The member said, What have you done over the last nine years? For the benefit of the member for Spence, lets run through it. Together with the community of Karoonda East Murray, we purposed drought funding to build—guess what? A childcare centre. In the community of Lameroo, together with my support and the policies of the previous coalition government, guess what we built? A childcare centre. Then we have the community of Pinnaroo. As a proud South Australian, the member for Spence should visit some of these communities. They are not far from where he lives. Guess what we built in Pinnaroo? A childcare centre.But I dont want to talk about those successes. I actually want to talk about the Kingston community in the south-east of South Australia. There are a couple of Kingstons in my electorate: theres Kingston on Murray and Kingston South East, the home of Larry the lobster. I can see the member for Spence nodding; I think he wants to come for a holiday in the south-east. Ill host him. But I really need to tell the House about the Kingston South East community and in particular the Kingston Early Learning and Childcare Services Working Group. This is a group of women—yes, gentlemen, theyre all women—who got together in Kingston because their area was a desert. They wanted to get back in the workforce—nurses, farmers, administrators and otherwise—but they couldnt, so they began a campaign to get child care for Kingston. Im so proud of these women because, while many of their children are now in high school, they kept fighting, not for their own personal interests but for their broader community.In the lead-up to the last election, through the Capital Grants Program, which you might realise was scrapped in last nights budget, we committed $1.8 million for a purpose-built childcare centre in Kingston. Now, the member for Spence and I can agree on some things; I think wed agree on more than many might think. But I want to give a shout-out to the former shadow minister, the member for Kingston, because during that campaign I contacted her and said: Look, were going to make this commitment. Wouldnt it be great if it was matched? And in fact it was matched, and this morning on local radio in South Australia Dr Anne Aly confirmed that funding. That was, for the benefit of the member for Spence, the member for Barker bringing the then opposition, kicking and screaming, to that outcome.Im pleased because were here to address affordability and accessibility. The problem with this bill, with respect, is that it does nothing about accessibility. It provides $4.5 billion, more money than you can fly a rocket ship over, but it doesnt buy one additional place. It doesnt train one additional early childhood educator. I dont want you to take my word for it; I want you to hear directly from those outstanding women from the Kingston South East Early Learning and Childcare Services Working Group, who recently addressed a Senate committee:We have a very small rural care service … where demand far exceeds supply. This issue is all too common in rural areas.They said this issue was far reaching and had affected their community for 40 years.The mission of our working group is for all children in the Kingston area to have equal access to early learning and childcare opportunities—hardly putting the man on the moon.This shortage of early learning opportunities has really impacted our community in a negative manner for the past 40 years.We talk about the gap. There are lots of gaps. Childcare deserts are most likely to occur, they say, in small towns with populations under 2,000 people.The bill refers to the right to work, the right to education and the right to equality. If this is true then why does our geographical location disadvantage us so much?You see, this is the point. This bill is about what postcode you live in. If you live in a metropolitan postcode and you earn a joint income of under $520-odd thousand, you will get access to cheaper child care. As I said at the beginning, we think cheaper child care for 1.2 million Australians is a great thing. But its got to sit hand in glove with programs and government policy to provide accessibility in these deserts. They go on, as I have, to say:Cheaper childcare subsidies are most welcome; we support this element of the bill.Have a think about how gracious these Australians are. They have been without sufficient child care for 40 years, but theyre still happy for their fellow Australians to have access to cheaper child care. However, reform is needed to prevent market failure in rural and disadvantaged areas. State and federal governments must co-ordinate and implement a universal strategic approach to improving access to child care in regional areas. If those opposite are looking to develop a policy around access to early-age education in this country, they would do well to get in the car, drive to Kingston, take a photo out the front of Larry the lobster, then sit down with the women of the Kingston SE Early Learning and Childcare Services Working Group, because they live it. They get it. Quite frankly, if those opposite think they have solved the childcare quandary in this country with this bill then they have only to speak to them to understand how far they are from the mark.
